security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill containing markdown files and YAML configuration templates for the open-source Grype vulnerability scanner. All 332 static findings are false positives - the scanner flagged shell command examples (177), URL references (45), and environment variable patterns (27) in documentation as security issues. No executable code exists. This skill provides documentation and workflows for container vulnerability scanning but performs no actual scanning, network access, or file system operations beyond reading its own documentation files.

content.user_title: Scan container images for vulnerabilities with Grype
content.value_statement: Container images often contain known security vulnerabilities in operating system packages and application dependencies. This skill provides guided workflows for scanning images with Grype, interpreting CVSS scores, prioritizing based on CISA KEV indicators, and integrating security gates into CI/CD pipelines.
actual_capabilities: Scan container images for CVEs using the Grype vulnerability scanner
Interpret CVSS severity scores and EPSS exploit probability ratings
Identify CISA Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) in scan results
Configure CI/CD pipeline security gates with severity-based fail thresholds
Prioritize vulnerability remediation using threat intelligence indicators
Generate vulnerability reports in JSON, SARIF, and CycloneDX formats
limitations: Requires external installation of Grype and Docker tools
Does not perform actual scanning itself - provides documentation and workflows
No automatic remediation - only guidance on fixing identified vulnerabilities
Relies on external vulnerability databases (NVD, CISA) for CVE data

use_cases.title: CI/CD Security Gates
use_cases.description: Integrate container scanning into build pipelines with severity-based fail thresholds to block vulnerable images from reaching production.

use_cases.title: Vulnerability Triage
use_cases.description: Prioritize remediation efforts using CVSS scores, EPSS probabilities, and CISA KEV indicators to focus on actively exploited vulnerabilities.

use_cases.title: Pre-Deployment Scans
use_cases.description: Scan local container images before pushing to registries to catch and fix vulnerabilities early in the development cycle.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Scan

output_examples.input: How do I prioritize which container vulnerabilities to fix first?
output: 1. CISA KEV vulnerabilities (actively exploited in the wild) - fix immediately
2. High EPSS scores (>10%) - high probability of exploitation
5. CVSS Medium (4.0-6.9) - moderate impact, schedule remediation
6. CVSS Low (<4.0) - informational, address when time permits

best_practices: Set fail-on thresholds appropriate for each environment - critical for production, high for staging, medium for development pipelines.
Use SBOM-based scanning with Syft for faster re-scans during development without re-analyzing full container image layers each time.
Document all suppressed vulnerabilities with justification and review expiration dates to maintain audit trail and prevent forgotten exceptions.
Integrate SARIF output with GitHub Security or security dashboards for centralized vulnerability tracking across all projects.
anti_patterns: Ignoring low-severity vulnerabilities without assessment - some may indicate deeper security misconfigurations or deprecated packages.
Using overly broad ignore rules that suppress legitimate vulnerabilities across all packages instead of targeting specific false positives.
Scanning only new images during deployment - re-scan production images weekly to catch newly disclosed CVEs affecting existing deployments.
Setting fail-on thresholds too high (critical only) in CI/CD, allowing high-severity vulnerabilities to reach production environments.

faq.question: What container platforms does Grype support for scanning?
faq.answer: Grype scans images from Docker, podman, OCI registries including ECR, GCR, and Docker Hub. It analyzes Alpine, Ubuntu, Red Hat, Debian, and other Linux distributions.

faq.question: How often should I update the vulnerability database?
faq.answer: Run grype db update before each scan or at minimum once daily. New CVEs are published continuously, so daily updates ensure you catch recent disclosures.

faq.question: Can I use Grype without Docker installed?
faq.answer: Yes, Grype can scan directories, SBOM files in Syft, SPDX, or CycloneDX formats, and local tar archives. Docker is only required for live container image scanning.

faq.question: How is my scan data handled and transmitted?
faq.answer: Grype downloads vulnerability metadata from public databases like NVD and GitHub Advisory Database. No scan results are transmitted anywhere unless you explicitly configure output to external systems.

faq.question: Why does Grype report vulnerabilities in packages I do not use?
faq.answer: Grype scans all packages present in the image including transitive dependencies. Use the --only-fixed flag to show only vulnerabilities with available patches or create .grype.yaml ignore rules for confirmed false positives.

faq.question: How does Grype compare to other container scanners like Trivy or Snyk?
faq.answer: Grype is open-source, lightweight, and integrates well with CI/CD systems. Trivy offers more integrated registry scanning features and commercial options. All three scanners use similar vulnerability database sources.
